title: Introduction
description: Welcome to the AstroGlass documentation.
content: AstroGlass is a premium Astro theme designed for startups and creators who want to stand out. It features a unique Glassmorphism design system built on top of Tailwind CSS v4. Why AstroGlass? - Premium Design: 6 complete theme variants with depth and blur effects. - Hybrid Performance: Statically generated content with server-side capabilities. - Developer Experience: Type-safe content collections and easy configuration. - Full i18n: Built-in support for 7 languages, easily extensible. What's Included? The template comes with 6 fully designed themes, each providing 12+ page sections (Hero, About, Features, Pricing, Testimonials, FAQ, CTA, Contact, Header, Footer, plus new Landing Page sections), a dedicated Portfolio Page, a custom 404 page, plus a blog system and full documentation.

title: Theming System
description: Understand the core architecture of the dynamic theming system, including CSS variables, theme registry, and variant rendering.
content: AstroGlass features a highly flexible dynamic theming system built on top of Tailwind CSS v4 and Astro's component architecture. Architecture Overview The theming system consists of three main layers: 1. Theme Registry: Definitions for each theme in . 2. CSS Custom Properties: Theme-aware variables defined in . 3. Dynamic Rendering: The page dynamically renders the correct component variant for each section. Theme Registry Every theme is registered in . This centralizes theme metadata and makes it available to the entire application. - src/ - config/ - themes.ts Each theme definition includes: CSS Variables Theme-specific colors and effects are controlled through CSS custom properties. Variables are scoped to a attribute on the or tag. Components consume these via or Tailwind utilities: Variables use short names (, , , , , , ) to stay consistent with the DaisyUI-inspired naming convention used throughout the project. Dynamic Component Rendering Theme pages are rendered by . This file uses a component map to dynamically select the correct variant for each section: Each section variant is a self-contained Astro component. It uses internally for all text â€” no external props are needed. This allows each theme to have completely different HTML structures while maintaining a uniform API. Creating a New Theme 1. Add Theme Definition Add the theme definition object to . 2. Define CSS Variables Define the new theme's CSS variables in . 3. Create Section Components Create theme-specific component variants for each section, e.g., . 4. Register in Component Map Add the new theme's components to the in . 5. Add Translations Add any new localized strings to the JSON files in .

Colors are defined as HSL values (without the wrapper), allowing Tailwind's opacity modifier syntax to work correctly. Components consume these variables via Tailwind utility classes or : To change the site's color scheme, update the HSL values in . For theme-specific overrides (light/dark mode, per-theme colors), use selectors in . Adding Custom Fonts 1. Place font files in or import from Google Fonts in . 2. Define rules in . 3. For localized pages, we use separate directories: - src/ - pages/ - [...lang]/ â€” Dynamic Locale Routing - index.astro â€” Homepage (All Languages) - [theme].astro â€” Dynamic theme demo pages (e.g., /liquid, /ru/glass) - [theme]/portfolio.astro â€” Dynamic portfolio pages - blog/ â€” Blog pages - docs/ â€” Documentation pages - privacy.astro â€” Privacy Policy - terms.astro â€” Terms of Service - 404.astro â€” /404 Error page - about.astro â€” /about (Unlocalized) Theme Demo Routing Theme pages are generated dynamically from the theme registry. Adding a theme to with automatically creates a route at . title: Glassmorphism
description: Understanding the design philosophy behind AstroGlass.
content: AstroGlass implements a modern take on glassmorphism â€” creating interfaces that feel layered, transparent, and premium. The Recipe The glassmorphism effect is achieved through four key CSS properties working together: 1. Backdrop Blur: We use for the frosted effect. 2. Translucency: Background colors use alpha channels (e.g., ). 3. Borders: Subtle 1px borders () define the edges. 4. Shadows: Soft, colored shadows create depth and elevation. This combination creates a sense of hierarchy and modernity. Practical Usage In AstroGlass components, you'll see this pattern applied as Tailwind utility classes: For dark themes, the effect is often layered with gradient backgrounds: Theme Variations Each theme in AstroGlass interprets glassmorphism differently: | Theme | Glass Style | |-------|-------------| | Liquid | Organic shapes with fluid blob backgrounds | | Glass | Classic frosted panels with depth | | Neo | Bold contrast with sharp edges | | Luxury | Gold-tinted translucency with premium shadows | | Minimal | Subtle, barely-there transparency | | Aurora | Gradient mesh backgrounds with geometric structure | The intensity of blur, opacity, and border effects can be adjusted per-theme through the CSS variables in . Look for , , and related custom properties.
